trial_identification.studytitle: Compression Stockings and Recovery in marathon runners.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A study into 18-65 year old marathon runners and the recovery benefits of compression socks following marathon racing quantified by fatigue levels, muscle soreness, and recovery measured in a timed, Heart rate monitored graduated treadmill run to exhaustion compared to sham stockings.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Normal musculoskeletal and cartilage development and function

interventions.interventions: Commercially available Jobst Compression socks giving lower limb compression with a pressure at ankle of 30-40mmHg. Worn continuously for 48 hours starting within 1 hour of completing the marathon.
interventions.comparator: non-compressive Stiva socks giving no lower limb compression with a pressure at ankle of 0-1mmHg. Worn continuously for 48 hours starting within 1 hour of completing the Melbourne marathon.

primaryOutcome.outcome: muscle soreness measured using a visual analog scale between 1-10
perceived fatigue measured using a visual analog scale between 1-10

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Graded treadmill run to exhaustion. Protocol involves a 5min warmup at 4km/hr and 2% gradient. Treadmill is then progressively increased in speed by 2km/hr every 2 mins until exhaustion. They will have access to 1x700ml bottle of comercially available gatorade sports drink throughout the run. Exertion will be measured using a polar heart rate monitor and average and maximum heart rate throughout the test will be recorded.
Time Trial to exhaustion perceived exertion. This will be measured using the visual analog Borg's Rating of perceived Exertion scale every 2 minutes into each treadmill stage.

trial_design.concealment: Participants voluntarily enrolled through marathon newsletters. Participants blinded randomised by use of computer random number sequence generation.
trial_design.sequence: random number sequence generation created by computer software.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: My study is to investigate the possible benefit of lower limb compression stockings on recovery following an endurance running event. I will ask the participants to perform a 10km running time trial on a treadmill with heart rate and perceived exertion monitoring. This will be done 2 weeks before and 2 weeks after the Melbourne marathon. The participants will be given either compression tights with a high compressive value or tights with no compression to wear for 48 hours after the marathon. They will be asked to record muscle soreness and fatigue levels in the 7 days following the marathon.
